What does this mean for contract upgrades using @zeppelin_os or any other delegatecall-based upgradeability pattern?

1070101203197935616.text:
3. Governance & economic model.

Designing & codifying the right governance and economic model from Day 1 is impossible. They should be introduced not all at once, but carefully, thoughtfully & gradually tested with users. I'm inspired by how @zeppelin_os & others are doing this.

1053024060958011393.text:
Once in the wild, smart contracts need better ways to push on-chain updates, while also leveraging fixes others have made (many eyes, shallower bugs). 

@ZeppelinOrg & @AragonProject collaborating to that end, with "EVM Packages" :https://blog.zeppelinos.org/open-source-collaboration-in-the-blockchain-era-evm-packages/?utm_source=placeholder&utm_medium=social&utm_campaign=evm-packages …

1052936590803251200.text: EVM packages is a new trend we see coming in open source development for smart contractshttps://blog.zeppelinos.org/open-source-collaboration-in-the-blockchain-era-evm-packages/ …

1052923796531884032.text:
EVM Packages by @zeppelin_os & @AragonProject: "a smart contract app can reuse on-chain building blocks provided by other developers and opt in to bug fixes and improvements in the future."

Effectively providing granular packages of smart contract code!https://blog.zeppelinos.org/open-source-collaboration-in-the-blockchain-era-evm-packages/ …

1003887294871265280.text: on sanity checks to prevent messing up contract storage. @ZeppelinOrg latest proposal on unstructured storage is more more elegant. And after writing over 500 scenario tests, I suggest to those looking into proxy patterns or upgrade routes, that this is what you want.

1000470826804707328.text:
To get started, simply install ZeppelinOS:
npm install --global zos

And then initialize your project:
zos init <name> [version]

Now you can build and upgradeable app or use the on-chain standard libraryhttps://github.com/zeppelinos/zos-cli …
